title: Luxembourg PM: I’ll back a Brexit extension but we need a clear plan
text:
In an interview in his office, Xavier Bettel told POLITICO he didn't want to close the door on London | Sean Gallup/Getty Images Luxembourg PM: I’ll back a Brexit extension but we need a clear plan A no-deal Brexit is ‘the scenario I don’t want,’ says Xavier Bettel.

LUXEMBOURG — If the U.K. provides a good reason for a Brexit extension, Luxembourg's prime minister would accept it, but he has "no clue" what the British government wants.

In an interview in his office, Xavier Bettel told POLITICO he doesn't want to close the door on London, after the House of Commons voted to force Boris Johnson to seek a delay until the end of January if he can't get a deal approved by October 19 — much to the British prime minister's annoyance.

But if there is to be an extension beyond the current deadline of October 31, there will need to be a good reason, Bettel said.

“For the moment, I have just one deal on the table," said Bettel of the Withdrawal Agreement that has been rejected by the House of Commons three times. "I don’t know why we should have a new delay, why we should have a new deal, this deal is the best possible deal.

“If there’s reason [for a delay] I’ll accept, but I still have no reason, I still have no clue what they want.”

The Luxembourg PM said he doesn't think Brexit complications would cause problems for the handover at the European Commission.

In Bettel's view, the ball is firmly in the U.K.'s court. “It’s not on me to say that they have to do this and this to get a new delay, they have to tell us why they need a new delay, and then I’ll exchange [views] with my colleagues” in the European Council.

“I’ve never seen such a disunited Kingdom that we have at the moment, there’s no United Kingdom anymore," he said, adding that the entire Brexit process was "a problem of the Tories, to keep internal peace.”

A no-deal Brexit is "the scenario I don’t want, but time is ticking,” he added.

Bettel said there is no one sector he is particularly worried about if there's no deal, but he is concerned about ordinary citizens in his country who are asking "'how will we get to the U.K? We’ll need a visa? Are we able to work in the U.K.?' This uncertainty for our citizens is for me the biggest nightmare.”

Bettel was reluctant to talk about opportunities as a result of Brexit for Luxembourg, a financial hub. “I was not like some other colleagues who went to London to say 'leave the country' ... because whether we want it or not London, is still our neighbor ... I was not the pushy one, saying 'leave London, come to us,' a bit like hyenas.”

The Luxembourg PM said he doesn't think Brexit complications would cause problems for the handover at the European Commission, with Ursula von der Leyen officially taking over from Jean-Claude Juncker on November 1. As a result, he doesn't think Juncker and von der Leyen both need to be at the October summit of EU leaders (“you cannot have two popes in the same room”).

Bettel also seemed puzzled about reports that Johnson is hoping to find ways to get around the new law requiring him to request a Brexit delay if there's no deal, even if that means risking going to jail.

“I’m the second power, the first power is my parliament, so in my country when parliament decides, I do,” Bettel said.
description: A no-deal Brexit is ‘the scenario I don’t want,’ says Xavier Bettel.
